Award.AwardTitle: Soft Robotics to Broaden the STEM Pipeline

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to increase female interest in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) careers through the emerging field of soft robotics. Soft robotics diverge from other robotics in that they leverage materials science (understanding how materials stretch and deform), chemistry (polymer synthesis), and biology (bio-inspired design) to provide aids for human needs. This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue STEM careers by exploring the inspiration that soft robotics might afford. The focus is a unit within a high school freshman engineering course. Results of this project will include the development and testing of curriculum that has the potential to broaden participation. The International Technology and Engineering Educators Association STEM Center for Teaching and Learning will disseminate it to 50,000 students annually.

This project will test the hypothesis that the implementation of soft robot design experiences improves learning, motivation, engineering self-efficacy and interest in engineering careers as compared to traditional robot design experiences. This development and study is contextualized in a course required of many 9th grade students called Foundations of Technology, which is the freshman-level technology and engineering education course provided by the Engineering by Design core program. It is taught in over 270 school districts across 23 states to about 100,000 students annually. The study will employ a design research framework to develop the 8-hour unit and study its implementation in 11 classrooms with a total of 660 students in the Carroll County Public Schools. Measures include the Situational Motivation Scale and the Longitudinal Assessment of Engineering Self Efficacy. In Year 3, the project will implement an efficacy study to compare results of the soft robotics unit with the unit implemented traditionally in the Engineering by Design program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall aim of this project was to increase female interest in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) careers through the emerging field of soft robotics. During the project period, we tested the hypothesis that the implementation of soft robot design experiences improves learning, motivation, engineering self-efficacy, and interest in engineering careers as compared to traditional robot design experiences. Our approach was iterative: we developed a soft robotics curriculum, implemented the curriculum in classrooms, and collected data related to changes in student interest and self-efficacy in the STEM disciplines. Each year, we modified our curriculum, implementation approaches, and data collection instruments to refine our study.  

The study was contextualized in a course required of many 9th grade students called Foundations of Technology, which is the freshman-level technology and engineering education course provided by the Engineering byDesign core program. The study employed an 8-hour curriculum unit and was implemented in 91 classrooms by 18 teachers with a total of 2471 students in 2 partner public school districts. For the unit, we introduced a modular and reconfigurable mold for flexible design of pneumatic soft robotic grippers made from molded silicone. The modular mold enabled students to understand how design choices would impact system performance. We further demonstrated a sufficiently high rate of student success in designing and constructing functional soft robotic grippers using the developed modular mold kit.

Through our quantitative data collection, we consistently demonstrated that learning, motivation, engineering self-efficacy, and interest in engineering outcomes are comparable between soft and traditional robot design experiences. In the final year of the project, our quantitative data showed that the soft robotics experiences have significantly increased girls’ tinkering self efficacy which serves to mitigate the gender disparity that was observed in traditional robotics experiences. Finally, our qualitative data, including direct observation, interviews with teachers and students, and design notebooks, suggested that soft robot design experiences improve motivation and interest in engineering for underrepresented groups in STEM as compared to traditional robot design experiences.

The results of this project have been sustainably integrated into the International Technology and Engineering Educators Association Engineering byDesign™ course called Advanced Technological Applications. This is a yearlong, upper high school course has national and international dissemination. We made small changes to transition the pedagogical approach from the current 9th grade target audience to a 10th-12th grade audience. The soft robotic learning experiences are presented in the advanced course in combination with more traditional electromechanical programmable robotics in a seven week robotics segment of the course. National and international professional development began in March of 2018 with a kickoff at the International Technology and Engineering Educators Association Annual Conference.
